like.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: similar to something else, or happening in the same way
like.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Her hair is dark brown like mine.
A club should be like a big family.
My experience is very much like that described in the book.
Sometimes you sound just like (=exactly like) my mum!
He’s growing more like his father every day.
He looked nothing like (=not at all like) the man in the police photograph.
The garden looked like a jungle.
At last he felt like a real soldier.
like.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Things like glass, paper, and plastic can all be recycled.
Try to avoid fatty foods like cakes and biscuits.
like.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: In written English, people usually use for example, for instance, or such as rather than like:
packaging materials, for instance paper, glass, and plastic
Try to avoid fatty foods such as cakes and biscuits.
like.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: It’s not like Steven to be late.
be like somebody to do something
It’s just like her to run away from her responsibilities!
be like somebody to do something
like.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to enjoy something or think that it is nice or good
like.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I don’t really like classical music.
I like my coffee quite weak.
I don’t like it when you get angry.
How do you like living in London  (=how much do you like it)?
I quite like their new album.
The time I like best (=like most of all) is the evening when it’s cool.
I didn’t like the idea of being a single parent.
I don’t like talking in public.
I like to see people enjoying themselves.
One of the things I like about John is his sense of humour.
like.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to think that someone is nice or enjoy being with them
like.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Jessica’s really nice, but I don’t like her boyfriend.
She’s a lovely girl and I like her very much.
In time, I got to like her  (=began to like her).
like.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to approve of something and think that it is good or right
like.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: I don’t like the way he shouts at the children.
He’s never liked talking about people behind their backs.
I don’t like him taking all the credit when he didn’t do any of the work.
She doesn’t like to swear in front of the children.
like.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to try to do something regularly or make something happen regularly
like.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: I like to get up early and get a bit of work done before breakfast.
We like our students to take part in college sports activities.
like.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to click a Facebook ‘like’ button on a webpage to show that you like or agree with something
like.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: to think someone is sexually attractive
like.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: Do you think Alex likes me?
like.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2]: She likes to play tennis at weekends
like.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3]: Like doing something and like to do something both mean the same thing You use like to do especially when saying that someone does something regularly or often
like.translation[1].note_box[0].items[4]: Like  is not usually used in the progressive You say
She was liking to make cakes
like.translation[1].note_box[0].items[5]: In spoken English, people sometimes say I’m liking to describe their present feelings about something that is happening right now or that they have just seen or heard about
I’m liking this music – what is it?
like.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: like
to think that someone or something is nice
I like your dress – it’s a beautiful colour.
Do you like spaghetti?
What did you like about the movie?
I like travelling by train.
I like to see the children enjoying themselves.
Everybody liked Mr Schofield.
be fond of somebody/something
to like someone or something, especially something that you have liked for a long time or someone who you have known for a long time
Connie had always been fond of animals.
Over the years, I’ve become quite fond of him.
He had always been fond of drinking at lunchtime, perhaps too fond.
be keen on somebody/something
to like someone or something – often used in negative sentences
I like Maria but I’m not keen on her husband.
Our English teacher was very keen on Shakespeare, but I couldn’t stand him.
I was keen on all sports at school.
I know he’s keen on opera. Let’s take him to see ‘La Traviata’.
I’m quite keen on the idea of having a fancy dress party.
be into something
to like doing a particular activity or be interested in a particular subject – used especially by young people
She’s really into music at the moment.
What kind of films are you into?
have a thing about somebody/something
to like someone or something, especially something surprising or unusual
I’ve always had a thing about wolves.
He has this thing about tall women.
be partial to something
to like to have something – often used humorously
He’s partial to the occasional glass of wine.
something grows on you
used when saying that you begin to like something, especially something that you did not like before
I didn’t like the colour of the room at first, but it’s growing on me.
to like something very much
love/adore
to like something very much. Adore is stronger than love but is less common
I love the smell of coffee.
The children absolutely adore her books.
be crazy about something
to be extremely interested in an activity and spend a lot of time doing it or watching it
Jonah’s crazy about basketball.
She’s always been mad about horses.
have a passion for something
to like an activity very much, because it gives you a lot of pleasure or excitement
From a very early age he had a passion for fast cars.
To be a great performer, you have to work very hard and have a passion for the music you play.
be addicted to something
to like doing something so much that you spend all your free time doing it
My son’s addicted to computer games – he hardly ever comes out of his room.
I started watching the show out of curiosity, but now I’m addicted!
like.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: in the same way as. Some people consider this use to be incorrect
like.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: No one else can score goals like he can!
Don’t talk to me like you talk to a child.
like.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: as if. Some people think that this use is not correct English
like.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: He looked at me like I was mad.
It looks like it’s going to rain.
This meat smells like it’s gone bad.
like.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: used in speech to fill a pause while you are thinking what to say next
like.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: The water was, like, really cold.
I was just, like, standing there.
like.translation[5].definitions[0].examp: The second dispute was sorted out in a like manner.
They get on well together because they are of like mind.
Try to buy two fish of like size.
like.translation[6].definitions[0].defin: used after a noun to say that something is similar to or typical of the noun
